A New Era of Cooperation

As May begins, NASA is ready to begin the second Advanced Apollo mission: Apollo 27. This mission will study the southern highlands between Mare Imbrium and Mare Serenitatis. This mission is also notable for being the first space mission with a Western European as a crew member. The Soviets had already flown astronauts from the Warsaw Pact states into space on Soyuz, but with the rise of ESA they selected 4 astronauts who were sent to NASA for training, with 2 of them having been selected by NASA in their most recent Astronaut Group 9. On this mission, Dutchman Wubbo Ockels will be the first West European in space, and the first West European on the Moon. ESA is thrilled by NASA's welcoming of their astronauts, and the partnership between the two agencies is growing stronger every year. It has been the birth of a great partnership, one that will continue into the 1980s.

Columbia rolls out to 39B on April 30th, with the Habitat Module and supplies being loaded into the payload bay on May 6th. The crew perform a launch rehearsal a day before that on the 5th. The mission first attempts launch on May 9th, however an issue with the LH2 TSM leaking during fueling delays the launch to the night of the 10th. Technicians work around the clock the 10th to repair the TSM, and their efforts are successful. As fueling begins, no leaks are detected, and Columbia is GO for launch on May 10th, 1981.

MISSION OVERVIEW: STS-41-D |

Commander | Robert Overmeyer

Pilot | John Creighton 

Apollo 27 Commander | Robert Crippen

ALSM Pilot | Frederick Gregory

Scientist 1 | Sally Ride

Scientist 2 | Norman Thagard

Specialist 1 | James van Hoften

OV-102 "Columbia"

Objectives: Support Apollo 27 lunar mission.

A serene night liftoff of Columbia.

"Solid Rocket Motor Ignition and LIFTOFF of Columbia, supporting another manned mission to The Moon!"

Once on orbit, Columbia releases and docks with the Habitat Module, now beginning another one of the "most boring Shuttle missions" as they await the ALSM and LTV.

On May 14th, the Saturn III takes flight carrying the ALSM.

The ALSM successfully docks to the Habitat Module 15 hours after launch. The crew have to wait a whole week though, until the might Saturn A07 takes flight with the final piece of the mission.

The LTV saw a lot of improvements for this mission. Most notably revised solar arrays and better tank insulation. The engine as well saw a whole host of improvements, which will hopefully fix that overheating issue.

Successfully docking with the Habitat Module 16 hours after launch, the Apollo 27 stack is completed, and their crew settled in. Columbia returns with her 2 remaining crew of Overmeyer and Brandenstein, landing at the Cape.

With the Shuttle back on Earth, Apollo 27, now under the name Mayflower, begins Trans-Lunar Injection.

"Mayflower, Go for TLI."

TLI is successful, with the NTR motor having much better thermal characteristics.

A small correction is performed the next day for a proper lunar encounter.

3 days after TLI, a trio of burns put the LTV, and Apollo 27, in Low Lunar Orbit.

A few hours later, 4 Americans and 1 European are preparing to descend to the lunar surface.

(Note again: One more mission until I actually settled on an ALSM design, sorry for this inconsistency I just dabbled with a lot of designs. )

"1000 feet. Velocity is nominal."

"800 feet."

"600 feet."

"400 feet."

"200 feet."

"100 feet."

"75."

"50."

"30."

"20."

"10."

"CONTACT LIGHT."

"SHUTDOWN SHUTDOWN."

"Houston..."

"Mayflower has landed."

15 minutes after landing, the solar arrays would be extended.

The crew were given a few hours to rest after landing. But at 10:00 AM in the US, and 5:00 PM in the Netherlands, the crew begin their descent down the ladder to the surface.

Ockels would be second out, and upon stepping off the ladder onto the lunar surface, he would give the world these remarks.

"I can't begin to describe it. The wonder of this place. I am so captivated by its beauty. We are pushing the boundaries of what is possible, in this new era of cooperation."

Adequate words for a remarkable mission.

The first few days of the mission won't exactly be thrilling. Why? Well the astronauts are waiting on some wheels.

On May 24th, the first (and only) Saturn A02 takes flight carrying the Enhanced Exploration Roving Module, or EERM. This rover will permit greater travel across the lunar surface for the mission.

The EERM eventually arrives at the Moon on the 27th, and a modified LM Descent Stage brings it to the surface near the landing site of the ALSM.

Once on the surface, the Apollo 27 crew retrieve it, and test its instrument arm on a nearby rock formation to verify it is functioning properly.

The EERM is definitely a big step up from the LRV, however it begins to show some uhh... issues.

On May 28th, the crew embark on Geology Expedition 1. The main objective of Geology Expedition 1 is to setup a station on a hill about a dozen or so kilometers from the landing site. The pressurized EERM rover makes this traverse much more easy on the astronauts.

However not so much on the driver of the EERM. The little rover has shown to be just a tad unstable over uneven terrain like this, due to its narrow wheelbase and decent amount of power. The short porch at the back also has its drawbacks, leaving much of the equipment to be kept inside the rover, leaving less space for the crew.

These issues already have some people thinking about a redesign, but that's a problem for the future. The crew are stuck with this fella for now.

After the world's slowest 12 kilometer drive, the crew arrive at the intended site, and set up their equipment, before returning to the ALSM.

3 more of these expeditions are conducted to various sites before the end of the mission.

One big thing noticeable in the news, however, is the lack of Luna 9. Despite the Soviets boasting of their new and improved lunar mission to come while Apollo 27 is on the surface, it didn't. By the time Apollo 27 departs on June 8th, the Sokol rocket intended to launch the LK-700 is still in its assembly hangar, lacking the upper stage and LK-700.

Regardless of the no-show Soviets, Apollo 27 has been the most scientifically valuable moon mission to date, with a successful ascent back to the lunar surface on, as I mentioned, June 8th.

Trans-Earth Injection is successful, and Mayflower is heading home.

Arriving back at Earth on June 11th, the LTV performs 2 maneuvers to bring the mission back into Low Earth Orbit.

The MPCS then launches right on time June 12th, to return the crew.

Once the MPCS performs rendezvous, the ALSM undocks, vacating a port for the MPCS to dock to.

Once docked, the hatch is opened and the crew board the MPCS, then closing the hatch again, the whole process takes about 25-30 minutes. The surface samples are also transferred into the MPCS as well as returning equipment.

The MPCS then undocks, allowing the ALSM to redock to the LTV.

Despite the once again high costs of the mission, with reuse now possible for Apollo 28, NASA expects the price to drop significantly for the next missions. However, they're still taking a pretty penny out of NASA's budget, which is going to make building a lunar base in this decade rather difficult.

The MPCS then de-orbits, and returns for a splashdown in the Atlantic.

A gentle splashdown, concluding a fantastic mission to the Moon. Welcome home Apollo 27.

Despite its shortcomings in the cost and cadence department, Advanced Apollo is a remarkable achievement for NASA, and a true testament to what they are capable of. Although the future holds a new way of getting to the Moon, Apollo and its funny distant relative will be remembered as pioneering programs.

Family Portraits and Foggy Launches

The rest of June was rather boring for space, the US Navy did begin trials of a big submarine or something though. However, on July 4th, a certain Shuttle returns to the Cape.

Welcome back, Enterprise.

Enterprise left the Cape on December 2nd, 1979, and underwent 18 months of extensive overhaul at Palmdale during her first "Orbiter Maintenance Down Period" or OMDP 1. NASA hopes this has undone a lot of the issues that plagued Enterprise during her early service. Over those 18 months, Rockwell practically took the Shuttle apart and put it back together, with many key systems being upgraded or replaced outright. To summarize the work done:

  • New hydraulics system used by the other 4 Orbiters
  • Roughly 100 miles of wiring replaced
  • Re-seated APU position and new APU exhaust ports
  • Totally replaced aft section engine plumbing
  • New body flap taken from at the time under construction Atlantis
  • Structural strengthening in the mid fuselage
  • New RCS plumbing
  • 15,000 TPS tiles replaced

 

With all of those upgrades and changes, on top of general repairs and maintenance, NASA hopes Enterprise will be on par with the later Orbiters of Discovery and Atlantis.

Since all Orbiters are finally on the ground at the same time, and Discovery a few weeks from rollover to the VAB for 41-E, NASA decides to take some family photos.

The result are some of the most awe-inspiring images ever.

All 5 Orbiters, in one image.

These photos became an instant PR success, headlining many newspapers the day after their release.

But once the photos were taken, the Shuttles were rolled back to the OPF, with Enterprise going to a hangar near the OPF for some extra work. Discovery would be set upon the Orbiter Transporter System, and rolled over to the VAB to be stacked for her next flight, STS-41-E.

This is a routine mission to Skylab, carrying a new 5 person crew and supplies for their stay. But it would turn into an interesting series of events leading to one of the most magnificent launches to date.

Discovery would be stacked on the side of the External Tank on July 25th, with a morning rollout ahead of some rain on August 8th. 

A successful rehearsal on August 15th, with the countdown winding down on August 20th for launch.

"T-12, 11, 10,"

"9,"

"We have a Go for Main Engine Start,"

"7, 6, 5,"

All engines running, 3..." 

"Cutoff. Shutdown Shutdown."

"We have a Redundant Set Launch Sequencer Abort."

For the first time, the Shuttle's onboard computers triggered a launch abort right as the Shuttle's main engines started up.

Thankfully, the problem wasn't too serious, as it was a simple bit error in the system monitoring engine startup, which gave a wild reading and triggered a shutdown of the engines. After some software tweaks on the pad, and replacement of the HBOIs in the Tail Service Masts, Discovery was ready to launch again 3 days later on August 23rd.

But as the countdown proceeded, the fog rolled in to the KSC, leading to a spectacular launch.

"T-12, 11, 10, 9, We have a GO for Main Engine Start, 7, 6, 5, all 3 engines running."

"3, 2, 1..."

"BOOSTER IGNITION AND LIFTOFF OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE DISCOVERY WITH THE NEW CREW OF SKYLAB!"

The fog amplified the brightness of the SRBs, turning night into day at the KSC as awestruck spectators watched the Shuttle climb into the night sky.

The mission is otherwise standard, with a successful 1 week stay on the station.

Discovery de-orbits on Flight Day 10, for a landing at the Cape.

With the conclusion of STS-41-F, NASA now heads into the end of 1981 with just one Shuttle launch remaining. 1981 hasn't been the Shuttle's strongest year, but 1982 is set to have a flurry of activity.

Dos DOS and The SPAM

1981 winds down rather calmly, with only a few notable events.

On October 10th, the second DOS module of Salyut 7A launches aboard a Sokol B. The third DOS was deemed unnecessary after some cost analysis, and thus this is the second and final component of the station.

Salyut 7A now complete. Nothing too fancy, but it'll do until Mir comes around.

Speaking of Mir there has been a lot going on with that station. With Valentin Glushko gaining ever more power within the Soviet space program, he has pushed more and more for his new Energiya rockets to be involved. After a few months of some tug of war between him and the other design bureaus involved with Mir, he got his way. Mir will look quite different from its original design, with VKK and Energiya being pushed more into the design. With this new design, the Soviets hope to really compete with Skylab.

The politics of the Soviet space program have many worried, it's become a war for fame and getting your way, and it's one of the (many) reasons the centralized and well organized NASA has pulled so far ahead. If the Soviets want to stay in this thing, they might have to learn a thing or two from their enemy.

As the Soviets ponder their future, NASA is pondering the ice caps. As they prepare to launch the final Shuttle mission of the year, STS-41-F. This is the second flight of Shuttle Atlantis, and will carry the GLACIER satellite to orbit. The Shuttle is also carrying the second SPAS on this mission. GLACIER's deployment will be a little unique because of how its being stored in the payload bay.

You see, most Shuttle payloads are integrated into the payload bay on the launchpad through the Rotating Service Structure. This is an interesting way of doing things, but it works. To make this process easier for some payloads, however, NASA has developed the Universal Shuttle Payload Carrier. Functioning more traditionally, all you have to do is put your payload in the USPC, which is then loaded into the Shuttle's payload bay with ease. It minimizes the work needing to be done, and eases any technical challenges.

GLACIER will be the first to use the USPC. 

Containers aside, Atlantis lifts off into the afternoon skies on November 10th, 1981.

"AND LIFTOFF OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE ATLANTIS AND THE 5 CREW OF MISSION 41-F!"

\

I told them to not point it near the Sun, but do they listen to me? No.

Now on orbit, the astronauts can look out the aft flight deck to see the USPC and SPAS II.

GLACIER is deployed on Flight Day 3.

GLACIER requires a polar orbit, and although Atlantis has launched into practically the highest inclination the Shuttle can get to from the Cape, it's not quite enough, so a kick stage has been made. While some consider it to be just a "Star 48 glued to an IUS avionics bus" NASA calls it the SPAM, or Shuttle Payload Assist Module, because everything needs an acronym, and frankly this is an excellent one.

GLACIER will use the SPAM to raise its apogee at the right time, which will make correcting the inclination with its own propulsion easier.

After a few days, GLACIER is operational, and ready to monitor polar ice levels.

Atlantis returns to a lower orbit, and deploys SPAS II.

The mission was originally intended to go for longer to allow the SPAS experiments to, well, go longer, but Fuel Cell issues have cut the mission short, so on Flight Day 7, SPAS II is retrieved.

The retrieval was a bit odd, but nevertheless it was retrieved, and the crew get a few hours of rest before Atlantis de-orbits for a landing at the Cape.

With the landing of Atlantis, the Shuttle's year for 1981 is concluded. Although not exactly a record setting year, it has paved the way for what is set to be an exciting year in 1982 and in 1983. 

Enterprise rolls out to 39B on December 15th, ahead of its planned return flight on January 10th. The oldest Shuttle will kick off the new year.

NASA is optimistic for the new year, with the appointment of John Young as NASA's new Administrator, the agency seems to be taking a step in the right direction for the future. The Shuttle will continue to be at the forefront of exploration, and many other systems will soon join it in NASA's fleet.

But the Soviets, oh those Soviets.

They're heading for a comeback.

Addendum

This is to cover some things I missed in the last post, mainly some smaller but important events.

June 1981: Saturn IG display opens at the Kennedy Space Center

The last built Saturn IG, which was ultimately not needed for flight, has officially gone on display at NASA's Kennedy Space Center, it is displayed horizontally next to the Saturn V first stage near the VAB. NASA hopes to eventually move it to a new visitor center.

August 1981: Voyager 2 Flyby of Saturn

The Voyager 2 spacecraft flew by Saturn in August, just 10 months since Voyager 1 did the same. It is now heading towards Uranus for a flyby expected at the start of 1986. Voyager 1 is now on its way out of the Solar System, leaving Voyager 2 to complete the Grand Tour.

October 1981: NASA orders development of expendable SSME variant for the Shuttle-Derived Launch System

NASA has contracted Rocketdyne to develop a simpler, and cheaper version of the Space Shuttle Main Engine for the SDLS rockets. NASA was originally considering a reusable engine pod for the new launch vehicle family but that has been moved down the line as a potential future upgrade.

November 1981: NASA enters final stages of SDLS design.

The SDLS rocket's design is nearly finalized, and NASA expects to contract out the design in the first quarter of 1982.

December 1981: Reagan visits Kennedy Space Center for the first time

President Ronald Reagan visited the Kennedy Space Center on December 15th, 1981, touring many facilities including the VAB, OPF, Mission Control, and Launch Pad 39A. The President also got a close up view of the under construction SAB. Reagan remarked "This place is a true testament to the capabilities of America's space program, and I put my full faith behind this excellent agency and the men and women part of it."

A New Year

1982 promises to be another exciting year for space exploration. The Shuttle is poised to finally break its record 7 flights in 1979, which was tied in 1980. There are 9 scheduled Shuttle missions for this year, with a few being incredibly important.

To kick things off, on January 3rd, NASA officially begins development of the Apollo Advanced Crew Operations Vehicle, or ACOV as it is usually known. This upgraded and modernized Apollo spacecraft will be the backbone of the Apollo Follow-On Program, which still doesn't have an official name for it yet. ACOV needs to be ready by 1984, which is when NASA needs it to be tested and considered ready for operation for the first AFOP mission, which is simply called AFOP-1 for now. ACOV has its doubters within the agency, as its launch system (the Shuttle) will have to be pushed to its absolute limit to get ACOV and its yet to be determined lunar boost stage into orbit. But with the SSME's continual improvement and uprated thrust provide the necessary performance.

But they're not just talking about ACOV on the Shuttle, it's also how some see it as a bit of a downgrade from Advanced Apollo. As compared to the mighty LTV assembly, 5 astronauts in ACOV on their way to the Moon alone isn't as grand or seemingly as capable. However, NASA sees ACOV as a proper re-focusing. These are only support vehicles, NASA's ultimate goal is a Moon Base, it has been since they began lunar exploration. ACOV's design is that of simplicity, utilitarianism even. It is an advanced and capable spacecraft, without a doubt, but it is designed to get the job done, that's it. With AFOP, there will only be 2 launches necessary for a lunar mission to get underway, 3 if refueling a nuclear tug for the ALSM is necessary. ACOV can launch and return the crew, which does remove MPCS from the architecture. However, ESA are finding other ways to contribute and get seats.

Speaking of nuclear tugs, the NERVA program, now re-organized into the Office of Nuclear Propulsion, has been directed to develop a new nuclear tug. This tug, under the working name "LTV Mk. II" will be a solely cargo focused tug, intended to carry the ALSM to lunar orbit. The current in-development concepts have 5 smaller NTR motors, with lessons learned from the large NE-G3 engine used on the original Lunar Transfer Vehicle. While it isn't solely for the ALSM, that will be its primary payload. The tug and ALSM are intended to be launched together aboard a larger config SDLS rocket, where the tug will then put the ALSM in lunar orbit, where it will await ACOV.

The ALSM is also seeing concept studies for it to become reusable, but there's nothing finalized on that yet. On top of that, NASA is beginning to lay out plans for a Lunar Space Station, under the name "Tranquility Space Station" as it will be known. This station is where ACOV will refuel in lunar orbit before returning home. As well as being an important place for experiments, samples, and other equipment to be stored before being returned to Earth.

This is the architecture of AFOP coming together, into a consolidated standard mission plan. At this point, NASA hopes they can get each AFOP mission to be less than 325 million dollars (~1 billion today) which is a massive cost reduction from Advanced Apollo, allowing NASA to hopefully conduct upwards of 3 missions per year, leading to a full fledged lunar base in the late 1980s, if all goes to plan. There are still a lot of things to be worked out, but the Apollo Follow-On Program is showing great promise.

Moving away from lunar programs, NASA's last year has been certainly interesting. Reagan, whether intentionally or not, has started a cultural revolution for NASA. The leadership of John Young is a stark change from that of the prior 2 decades. NASA has been lead by many great men, but for the first time it is being lead by an astronaut, someone who has been to space, someone who has experienced and truly understands the magic of spaceflight. Young has already spearheaded many popular changes. Improved employee benefits, higher salaries, and an overall positive reinforcement of good work culture and proper practices. Many NASA big-wigs have also been replaced. This massive shift from a huge bureaucratic leadership tree has been a breath of fresh air for everyone, and has allowed the agency to rid itself of many of the negative lingering culture and management issues that have been around since the late 60s.

This "Cultural Revolution" has so far been positive for NASA, although it is not evenly spread throughout the agency. The Shuttle program has, unfortunately, kept many holdouts of former leadership and a continual lingering presence of... shall I say suboptimal practice.

This is the thorn in NASA's side, and removing it will be very painful, but worth it in the long run.

With their affairs in order, there is a Shuttle on the launchpad to kick off the new year.

Enterprise is ready for flight again.

STS-51-A is intended to deploy the Solar Orbiting Observer, or SOO spacecraft. As the name suggests, SOO will orbit the Sun and study it. An interim upper stage and Star 48 are onboard to boost the spacecraft into its intended heliocentric orbit.

The launch is GO on January 10th, 1982.

"T-12, 11, 10,"

"We have a Go for Main Engine Start,"

"7, 6, 5, 4,"

"We have Main Engin-"

"Shutdown."

"We have had an RSLS abort."

"NO DATA FROM ENGINE 3."

"Houston there's red lights all over the place."

"Copy Enterprise, we're looking at what happened."

It would take 2 tense hours to ensure there were no more hydrogen fires at the pad, and get the crew out of the Orbiter. The footage from the pad cameras already indicated a very unusual event occurring with Engine 3, but when technicians performed inspections the next day they were stunned. The injector plate was ripped open, and many of the cooling channels in the nozzle were open as well, everything else was charred or otherwise damaged inside the engine. It is a near miracle that the engine didn't outright destroy itself.

NASA rolls Enterprise back into High Bay 1 on January 18th, and on the 20th Engine 3 is removed, where the extent of its damage is more visible. The engine is then sent to NSTL in Mississippi where NASA and Rocketdyne technicians will take it apart and figure out what happened. 

Moving back to Enterprise, the other 2 engines are removed just in case, and the set of engines designated for Atlantis due to fly next on 51-B are given to Enterprise. This work takes place over the rest of January and most of February.

The Shuttle program truly has no idea how lucky it was with Engine 3 still being in (mostly) one piece. Administrator John Young is rather involved after the incident, and visits Enterprise in the VAB while the engine in question is removed. He makes it of the utmost importance for the program to understand and rectify the issue. Which is partially responsible for the engine being sent to NSTL.

While NASA scratches its head over what exactly happened, the Soviets launch the first crew to Salyut 7A.

This crew will stay at the new station for 3 months, before returning home.

On February 20th, as Enterprise prepares to return to the launchpad, Rocketdyne submits the report on the Engine 3 malfunction. In the summary at the end, they state the following:

"No.3 Engine had 2 disabled injector posts, these posts are disabled by golden pins that are pushed up inside the injector. During the startup of No.3 engine, both disabling pins came loose, going through their injector, down through the injector plate itself, before hitting the wall of the nozzle, striking the cooling channels along it. The rapid and unusual sensor data triggered the RSLS to abort the launch. The engine in question is no longer flyable, and will be retained by Rocketdyne to, with the help of NASA, better understand fringe failure scenarios like this one."

It is, quite simply, such an odd failure scenario. But NASA and Rocketdyne have agreed to work on a better method of handling disabled injector posts.

The press is very confused, and can you blame them? A golden pin to disable an injector post? The press don't even understand what that means but they can clearly see it's a sketchy idea. This results in a lot of negative press for NASA, but they have no idea that it's just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the agency's issues. Issues that are, although actively being worked on by the new leadership, still linger especially in the Shuttle program.

However, NASA must move on and continue. Enterprise is rolled back out to 39B on February 25th. NASA decides to, finally exercising a bit of caution, conduct an FRF on February 29th to ensure the engines are all in working order for launch, slated for March 3rd. The FRF is a successful 20 second test, and final preparations are completed as Enterprise is GO for launch on March 3rd, 1982.

"BOOSTER IGNITION AND LIFTOFF, liftoff of Space Shuttle Enterprise, returning to flight on the 30th Space Shuttle Mission!"

Enterprise is now in orbit for the first time in nearly 2 and a half years.

Keeping with the theme of the mission, there are multiple issues with SOO's deployment, that push it all the way to Flight Day 3. But eventually, SOO and its boost stages rise out of the payload bay.

The series of 3 motors then later begins to boost SOO into heliocentric orbit.

The boosting phase is successful, and SOO deploys its many magnetometers and other instruments to begin its mission of solar research.

Enterprise then de-orbits on Flight Day 4, for a landing at Edwards AFB.

Enterprise has returned to space, in the most characteristically chaotic way. She is slated to fly again later in the year, and will be returned to the Cape by the Shuttle Carrier Aircraft for processing.

NASA has gotten through this first mission of 1982, hoping that the others will be much smoother.

The next one, maybe mercifully, is! Atlantis performs a standard Skylab supply run and crew rotation on STS-51-B, launching into the night skies on March 30th, and returning on April 9th.

STS-51-B is what the Shuttle, and NASA overall, needed after 51-A. Just a simple non-chaotic run to Skylab, which the Shuttle is getting pretty good at. 

With a month break until the next Shuttle flight, NASA is doing some public work for some major projects. Most notably publishing information about the planned Jupiter Orbiter spacecraft, which is now to be named Galileo in honor of the famed astronomer. This spacecraft is getting underway with assembly by now, and is slated to launch in 1985 aboard the Space Shuttle with Centaur.

For the current Jupiter Orbiter, NASA has officially set the End Of Mission (EOM) for Perdix in 1984, where it will flyby Ganymede to be sent out of the Jovian system and into a heliocentric orbit. The spacecraft's aging solar arrays are producing less and less power, while it runs out of propellant as well. Perdix has made many incredible discoveries, and laid the foundation for future exploration of Jupiter and its moons.

NASA also announces The Mars Collection, which is a series of 4 spacecraft to be launched in 1984 and 1986 to study Mars. 2 of them are practically new Viking missions, with an orbiter and a lander. The other two are solely Orbiters that will study Mars as well as its moons Phobos and Deimos.

For a long time NASA has wanted to ramp up its robotic programs again, but the funding consumption of the Shuttle and Advanced Apollo, coupled with the shrinking budget in the 70s, prevented that. Now NASA has the opportunities to explore the Solar System once more.

Speaking of the budget, Reagan submits his to Congress. This request is rather generous to NASA, not simply holding their funding, but finally increasing NASA's budget for the first time since 1972. The budget equates to 8.4 billion dollars (26 billion today) compared to the current budget of 7.2 billion (roughly 22.4 billion today) which is a considerable increase. Reagan has pledged that this is "just the beginning" and that he plans to provide the agency with more funding over time. The atmosphere is electric in NASA after this, the gates of opportunity are finally swinging back open. Which has lead many to begin thinking about where they've been wanting to go for so long.

But for the Soviets, they are at a time of re-focusing, as their manned lunar program has been officially cancelled. Despite its early 70s success it could not keep up with NASA and Apollo, even with planned efforts to change the mission architecture. The Soviets are now focused on 3 main things.

  • Mir
  • Robotic spacecraft
  • VKK

These 3 things will be the future of their space program through the rest of the decade and beyond. But they're not giving up on the Moon entirely.

They're thinking about getting on NASA's good side.

What better way to start than with a meeting in Low Earth Orbit?

 

НАСА приняло наши предложения по испытательному полету «Союз-Шаттл» с единственным условием, что астронавты не допускаются на палубы экипажа шаттла. Мы считаем эти условия приемлемыми и готовы к сотрудничеству.

Shuttle-Soyuz and The Rise of Ariane

     It's almost poetic, isn't it? The fiercest rivals coming together for a mission of cooperation in space. After 25 years of competing to be first in space, NASA and the Soviet space program are coming together for an incredible joint mission. A mission that will bring together the Soviet's trusty Soyuz spacecraft, and America's shiny new Space Shuttle. An incredible mission what will pave the way for future joint missions and international cooperation. That's at least how it seems on the surface, but those who are in the know, the Shuttle-Soyuz Test Project is an uneasy one. The Air Force mildly losing its mind over the national security threat this poses. NASA, in an act of appeasement, makes it a stipulation that the Soviet cosmonauts will only be allowed to enter the docking adapter, and go into the Spacelab module in the Shuttle's payload bay. The Soviets didn't really care about this, not like they needed to see the Shuttles flight decks anyway.

     However, it isn't just the "national security risks" that have placed a whole metric ton of tension on this mission. Simply the very idea of this cooperation would've been unthinkable just years ago. It's especially uncanny considering the current administration of Ronald Reagan, which seems to be foaming at the mouth to kill this joint mission if it finds even the slightest excuse to do so. But NASA, and the Soviets, know that very well. The USSR has been as cordial as possible make this mission work. But why? It's almost an uncanny level of cooperative behavior coming from a nation who but a year or two ago was shaking its fist in the UN every time the US spoke. This is something they've been subtly aware of ever since the Soviets unexpectedly approached NASA for the mission. What are they getting at?

   As has been said, the Soviet lunar program is cancelled, and there is no hope of it coming back anytime soon. With that painful truth accepted, they don't want to give up on lunar exploration by any means. And with a potentially gloomy future on the horizon, the Soviet space program could benefit from being on America, and NASA's, good side. So when they approached NASA about the Shuttle-Soyuz project a few months prior in December 1981, they hoped that it would lead up to potentially getting a seat on an Advanced Apollo mission. Gaining experience from working with NASA could potentially allow for a future revival of the lunar program. money allowing.

This is the genesis of SSTP, and a foundation for future cooperation that once seemed impossible. 

     Space Shuttle Atlantis was shoehorned in for mission 51-E, originally cancelled in September 1981 but re-added for SSTP. There will be minimal modifications needed, just the Soviets having to provide some technical help on a docking port swap to the passive Soviet port. The two countries did start developing APAS-75 together in the early 70s, but the Soviets dropped out of the project leaving the US to finish it themselves and adapt it for use on Skylab and the Shuttle. Therefore the Soviet version was never developed and thus it cannot be used for this mission. With this minimal preparation, the two countries agreed on an August 1982 date for the mission, with specific dates to occur closer to launch when logistics provide a clearer estimate.

     The public's reaction to the mission was mixed if not slightly negative in some regards. It's still the Cold War and while there has been progress towards better relations between the two superpowers, it's still rather frosty, and Reagan's attitude hasn't gone a long way towards improving that. But NASA sees it as a crucial opportunity to bridge a gap that has grown wider and wider in the 25 years of the Space Race, and a chance to bring the Soviets together with ESA and now Japan as partners for space exploration. The possibilities are near limitless if Shuttle-Soyuz goes right, and that's something NASA is excited for. Even if the Soviets are just trying to piggyback, it's better than nothing.

     Thus, with the mission slated for August, NASA moves to prepare Atlantis for the mission after returning from STS-51-B. As ESA looks towards its own future with a potential change upcoming.

     This is the Ariane 1 rocket, now under the operation of the first commercial space agency, Arianespace. In a slight kick in the back to the Europa rockets, CNES (France's space agency) has funded this rocket's development significantly, and has been trying to twist ESA's arm into getting it to replace Europa, but why?

Well, because it's better than Europa. That may be harsh but it is the case. This one rocket has already with 5 launches disrupted the commercial market, a market that the Shuttle is trying to break into. It has superior capabilities for a low cost, and has potential for easy future upgrades. Thus France has slowly but surely worn down ESA on Ariane, and it seems like Europa's days are numbered, as Ariane rises to take its place. This change also effects MPCS, as it will likely be the last to fly aboard Europa when it retrieves the crew of Apollo 28 at the start of next year.

This launch of Ariane 1 on May 2nd carried 4 German telecommunications satellites, further proving the launch vehicle's reliability and capability to deliver service.

On May 14th, Shuttle Challenger launches on mission 51-C for the Department of Defense. The payloads are classified, running under the suspiciously vague codenames "Monday" and "Tuesday" to keep everyone guessing.

The mission is successful with the DoD stating the payloads were deployed and are now operational afterwards. Challenger lands at Edwards on May 18th to conclude the mission.

Bundling up the Shuttle missions here before SSTP, Americans enjoy a Shuttle launch during their 4th of July afternoon festivities as Discovery launches mission 51-D carrying the second TDRS satellite to orbit. With a landing at the Cape on July 8th.

With the lead up missions out of the way. SSTP is NASA's primary focus. The new docking port is installed by early July, and Atlantis is rolled over to the VAB and stacked from July 18th-20th. With fit checks complete and Spacelab already in the payload bay, the Shuttle rolls out to 39B on August 6th, with launch now targeted for August 14th. 

As the sun begins to crest over the horizon on an August morning, Space Shuttle Atlantis takes to the skies on a mission of international cooperation.

"BOOSTER IGNITION AND LIFTOFF! LIFTOFF OF SPACE SHUTTLE ATLANTIS PIONEERING A NEW ERA OF COOPERATION IN SPACEFLIGHT!"

Once in orbit, Atlantis awaits Soyuz, scheduled to liftoff the next morning.

And liftoff it does! Soviet state television broadcasts the launch to the world, which is played on American news networks, allowing for the first time Americans to see a live Soviet rocket launch.

Soyuz launches successfully, and reaches orbit. Rendezvous will take about a day.

On the Shuttle's third day in orbit, visual on Soyuz is acquired, as the sturdy little Soviet spacecraft movies in closer to dock. Both spacecraft move closer and closer, until Soyuz is aligned for the final approach to dock.

"25 feet."

"Soyuz approaching now at a velocity of 1 foot per second."

"20 feet."

"15 feet."

"10 feet."

"Atlantis stabilizing now."

"5 feet."

"Soyuz slowing down to half a foot per second."

"3 feet."

"2."

"1."

"LATCH."

"DOCKING CONFIRMED!"

Mission controls in both Houston and Moscow erupt in applause, as docking is confirmed.

For the next 20 minutes, proper docking connection is verified, and the crews prepare to open the hatch and meet. 

26 minutes after docking, the hatch would open. With Charles Bolden greeting the Soyuz commander Vladimir Vasyutin with a handshake. A photo would be taken of this "handshake in space" by Mary Cleave and on the Soyuz side by Victor Savinykh. 

The cosmonauts would be awestruck by the scale of the Space Shuttle. With the Spacelab module in the payload bay being just about the size to hold Soyuz within it. 

The crews would begin 6 days of joint research in Spacelab, with focuses on flowering plants in zero gravity, and some space chemistry! The crew would also perform medical research, studying how pharmaceuticals could be produced in space for treatment on long-duration missions.

After these 6 groundbreaking days, the crews bid each other farewell, and Soyuz undocks from Atlantis, to return home. While the Shuttle would remain on orbit for another day.

Atlantis de-orbits the next day on Flight Day 10 for a landing at the Cape.

A groundbreaking mission concluded successfully. For both sides, SSTP has been exactly what they had hoped for. A positive outlook on future cooperation has been set down, and NASA has stated to the Soviets that they are willing to negotiate to give them a seat on Apollo 30.

However, Apollo 30's future is already in doubt.

 

Some Routine Stuff

     While Apollo 28 preparations are now underway after SSTP concludes, NASA has some business to attend to before that mission kicks off at the end of the year. Most notably, there have been some... issues with Advanced Apollo's 2 remaining mission after this upcoming one that raise questions about its ability to even complete the initial mission set before heading out. This is primarily because of the exorbitant and rising costs of the missions despite the LTV being reused for Apollo 29. Couple that with some of the worst contract structures NASA has ever made, and the hammer is looking likely to come down on the last 2 Advanced Apollo missions. Thankfully AFOP is well into development, and AFOP-1 is expected in 1985. Lessons have definitely been learned from Advanced Apollo, with AFOP only needing to fund ACOV and Tranquility for now, with a small portion of the cost going to ALSM reusability work and eventually a large chunk going to base development likely starting next year. This simplification and consolidation is what AFOP will need to be sustainable through the decade and beyond.

     The remaining business is mostly of the launch variety. As on September 19th, Grumman's Satellite Shuttle Vehicle launches a special little mission for NASA. You see, the agency had great ambitions for smaller (relatively speaking) projects and programs before the Great Budget Shrink, but through all of the cancellations one project managed to stay afloat due to its vague goals and low cost. That being the Earth-Moon System Project. The EMSP has faced many delays but it has finally showed up with its first of a few planned missions. This is 11 satellites for the Lunar Gravitational Influence Cluster (LGIC) which is intended to study how the Moon's gravity interacts with objects in Earth orbit. These are small satellites so they are well within the capabilities of SSV.

   SSV lifts off on September 19th, 1982 with the LGIC mission.

Another successful launch for the SSV, and the first step for the EMSP program.

Moving back to the Shuttle, Columbia launches STS-51-F on October 14th, which is the industry standard Skylab supply run and crew rotation. The launch is successful, with the crew of Skylab 15 returning on Columbia, and OV-102 becoming the first Orbiter to fly 10 times. However, the landing is a bit sketchy.

Columbia drifts very close to the edge of the runway during landing, primarily because of the less than stellar nose wheel steering on the Space Shuttle. Coupled with this is a blown tire and severe brake damage from a difficult crosswind landing.

NASA decides to stop landing the Shuttle at the narrow SLF for the time being until they can get a proper fixed Nose Wheel Steering system in place. Which makes Edwards the primary landing site for at least the next year.

Moving on to November, Challenger launches STS-51G with 3 communications satellites. A small note, NASA altered the naming scheme as of 51G to remove the hyphen between the digits and letter of the mission designation. Why? Mainly because it's easier to write and people never use it anyways, also it looks a bit nicer on paper.

Superficial naming scheme changes aside, STS-51G is another beautiful night launch, bringing the Shuttle into the commercial market at last.

"AND LIFTOFF OF CHALLENGER CARRYING A TRIO OF COMMUNICATIONS SATELLITES TO ORBIT!"

The Shuttle is also carrying an array of instruments on a modified payload bay truss known as the Shuttle Fixed Experiment Platform (SFEP) because once again, everything needs an acronym. 4 Getaway Special Canisters (GAS cans) are also present on this payload packed mission. NASA is hopeful that these types of missions, known as "Shuttle Rideshares" will catch on in the commercial market, making the Space Shuttle a leader in commercial satellite launching alongside the up and coming Ariane 1.

Continuing the theme of the mission, Challenger has a gorgeous early morning landing at Edwards.

With that out of the way, the path is clear to cap off 1982 with Apollo 28. Although this may very well be the last Advanced Apollo mission, it is going to be the best one yet by far.

But the Soviets are not happy with their plan not working like they had hoped.

They're going their own way. Again.

 

Stargazer

     To cap off the year, and also start next year, is the most ambitious Advanced Apollo mission to date. Although it may be the last, NASA fully intends for these incredible missions to go out in the best way possible. The landing site for Apollo 28 is on the edge of the Ocean of Storms where the lunar mare and the more standard terrain of the Moon meets. This area has been of great interest to NASA for some time, and it has finally been selected as a mission's landing site.

     Discovery will launch the crew and habitat module, on STS-51H, which will be the final Shuttle mission of the year. This mission will see the Shuttle finally break its 1979 record of 7 flights. NASA is optimistic that the Shuttle can soon exceed 10 flights a year, as the cost continually goes down. This is one of the few "cost positives" currently as NASA calls them. Advanced Apollo of course being the biggest "cost negative" right now. This cost positive/cost negative scale has been somewhat of a budgetary benefit, as NASA has had to adapt to these new plans for sustainability and lower costs. It's not all just about the budget and Congressional pressure, though. These massive contracts are sticking points with NASA management, as they feel the contractors have become complacent with such large and beneficial (for them) agreements.

Funding aside, the Saturn A07 rolls out to 39C on November 28th, with Discovery and Saturn III joining a few days later. The incredible "Moon Rocket Row" as stunning as ever. The A07 launches to refuel the LTV on December 5th in preparation for launch. This is the A07's final launch. Although it didn't do everything NASA had hoped for it, the mighty rocket has set a record that will likely never be surpassed, and demonstrated the engineering prowess of America.

The tanker successfully refuels the LTV, clearing the way for Discovery's launch a few days later.

MISSION OVERVIEW: STS-51H |

Commander | Henry Hartsfield Jr.

Pilot | Bryan O'Connor

Apollo 28 Commander | Donald Peterson

ALSM Pilot | Robert Gibson

Scientist 1 | David Leestma

Scientist 2 | Bonnie Dunbar

Specialist 1 | Frederick Hauck

OV-103 "Discovery"

Objectives: Support Apollo 28 lunar mission.

A winter liftoff on December 9th, 1982.

Since the LTV is being reused for this mission, Discovery is carrying a supply-packed Spacelab instead of the Habitat Module.

Discovery docks with the LTV the next day.

All that's left is the ALSM, which launches aboard what will be the last Saturn III. The Saturn III has made great contributions to the space program in its service, working with the Saturn IG to build Skylab early on, and since then to launch the ALSM for these lunar missions. It also utilizes an incredible feat of engineering in its first stage AJ260X solid rocket motor. The Saturn III will go down as one of the great American rockets, alongside the A07.

The launch is successful, and the ALSM docks with the LTV a few hours later after Discovery vacates the habitat module's docking port.

Discovery would move away from the LTV, and spend another day in orbit itself.

Discovery would land the next day, having to violate the no-landing rule at the Cape due to unfavorable weather at Edwards and White Sands. The landing was allowed due to good weather and minimal crosswind at the Cape.

Meanwhile, the crew of Apollo 28 officially gave their mission the callsign Stargazer, as they prepared for TLI.

"3, 2, 1..."

"Startup."

"Good startup on the LTV's nuclear engine."

After a few minutes, the motor would begin to throttle down as TLI concluded.

"We have good shutdown."

"Waiting for data readback..."

"Trajectory parameters are nominal, Stargazer is on its way to the Moon."

Nominal TLI, with only a small course correction necessary.

3 days later, a trio of maneuvers would bring the LTV back into lunar orbit, making it the first spacecraft to visit the Moon twice!

A few hours later, the crew board the ALSM, and descend to the surface.

"500 feet."

"Velocity is nominal. Descent rate looking good."

"375."

"300."

"225."

"150."

"75."

"50."

"30."

"15."

"5."

"CONTACT LIGHT."

"Houston, Stargazer, touchdown confirmed!"

The crew are given a few hours of rest, before beginning EVA 1.

Apollo 28 will be different, primarily focused on testing the "homestead" camp construction ideas of NASA for AFOP. There will be a few geologic traverses but primarily local area research and the setup of a massive array of instruments. Deep core samples are also of the utmost importance to this mission.

EVA 1 is focused first on the MESA bay being deployed and started, and deployment of the Passive Seismometer Experiment, which is being used for the first time since Apollo 11. The rest of EVA 1 is dedicated to a geologic traverse covering 3 kilometers, before the crew return to the ALSM for some rest and research.

EVA 2 deploys a few more instruments, but is also primarily dedicated to a Geologic Traverse. A notable deployment is the Large Solar Array (LSA) with is a testbed for base solar power.

EVA 3 is solely focused on deploying the rest of the surface instruments. With that, I'll go over all of the instruments deployed.

  • Passive Seismic Experiment
  • Communications Array
  • ESA provided TV camera
  • Heat Flow Experiment
  • Large Solar Array
  • Laser Reflector
  • The uhh... color gnome?
  • Tri-Axis Magnetometer
  • Radio Telescope
  • Lunar Gravity Experiment
  • Ultraviolet Telescope
  • Solar Wind Experiment
  • Ejecta Experiment
  • Active Seismometer

So yeah, there were quite a lot of things deployed on the lunar surface. But this has turned the landing site in a depot of data so to speak, with massive returns from the experiments.

The next 5 EVAs of the mission were primarily focused on geology and site exploration, covering the rest of the mission.

Finally, after a fruitful stay on the surface, Stargazer lifted off from the lunar surface on December 30th, 1982.

A few hours later, the LTV restarts its engine for the Trans-Earth Injection.

Arriving back at Earth on January 5th, 1983, the LTV brings the mission back into Low Earth Orbit. Now awaiting the launch of MPCS the next day.

The MPCS launches right on time, aboard what is likely the last Europa IIB, as ESA transitions to the Ariane rockets.

The crew and their many samples, including one large rock that they dug up which mildly concerned ESA for mass reasons, are transferred into the MPCS, which de-orbits a few hours after undocking.

Despite a slightly rough landing, Apollo 28 is back on Earth with a splashdown in the Atlantic. With the MPCS being hoisted onto the USS Nimitz, welcoming the crew back home.

With that, Advanced Apollo has concluded. Although it didn't live up to the high hopes NASA had for it, the program laid the foundation for sustainable exploration, and has taught NASA many necessary lessons for the future. It will leave a complicated legacy, but a memorable one no doubt.

There will be yet another Moon Gap as NASA makes way for the AFOP missions coming in a few years time.

Thus 1982 is concluded. The year saw many important events for spaceflight, and laid the foundation for many big changes over the next few years. While the Soviets may not be getting their ride to the Moon with NASA, they are determined now to get their own... again.

With a new promising relationship with Japan's space agency NASDA, America's space agency is preparing for the future, with a revitalized culture within NASA, and a promising budget increase for next year. 

Some notes to end the year:

  • The Republicans hold steady in the 1982 midterms, but still lose seats to the Democrats in both chambers, as Reagan pulls the country out of an economic slump as 1983 begins.
  • NASA tests a new version of the Space Shuttle SRB, with a Filament Wound Casing and several other improvements. These boosters with their striking black and white color are intended to be used for West Coast Shuttle launches.
  • Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev dies on November 10th, 1982. He is succeeded as leader of the nation by Yuri Andropov.
  • Valentin Glushko continues to consolidate power within the Soviet space program, as he pushes for further funding of his Energia rockets.
  • VKK BTS-02 is halfway through its construction.
  • The first SDLS Core Stage is nearing completion at Michoud, and it is expected to be delivered in the summer of 1983.
  • A team from Dryden and Ames present their Space Shuttle Technical Report for December 1982, detailing the future of the Space Shuttle system.
  • Ariane 1 is certified to launch MPCS on December 5th, 1982.
  • ESA and UK Space Agency representatives meet in Paris on November 15th.
  • The UKSA announces a new launch vehicle dubbed "Comet B" set to launch by 1984.

 

Мы рассчитываем поставить фюзеляж ВКК 1.01 не ранее середины следующего года.

Secrets, Strategic Defense, and Shuttles

     As 1983 begins, let us take stock, and understand where we are. This year is set to be an important one, primarily for the development of future systems as they get closer to their debut. But also for existing systems, the Space Shuttle, Iapyx as it nears Saturn, and practically the whole Soviet space program making a push towards new launch systems.

     For the Space Shuttle, it will be another 7 flight manifest for the year. What was originally a 8 flight manifest was cut down to 7 after Apollo 29 and 30 were cancelled, as STS-61H was intended to be a mission at the end of the year for Apollo 29 support. The Shuttle also has 2 classified missions on the manifest this year. A tug of war continues between NASA and the DoD over flight scheduling for these classified missions. For all the support they put behind the Shuttle, they've become an afterthought on the schedule. This has made the DoD rather upset, and has led them to begin the Complementary Expendable Launch Vehicle program. CELV, as it is called, will provide the DoD with new launch vehicles to replace its aging systems. This unfortunately includes the incredible Hercules rocket, but it won't be replaced until these new vehicles are fully up and running, which is slated for 1987. Martin Marietta is currently leading the way with proposals of an upgraded Titan III rocket. With Lockheed Convair and Douglas being interested but not submitting proposals as of the start of the year.

     The development of CELV could be considered a major blow to the Shuttle program, with the DoD clearly fed up with playing second fiddle to NASA's interest. Even though the Shuttle will fly increasingly more classified missions over the next few years, on top of starting flights out of Vandenberg next year. But it's also to support some big plans coming in the future, in which using the Shuttle alone would not suffice.

     In terms of lunar exploration, NASA has entered yet another "Moon Gap" as they prepare for AFOP to start in 1985. Development of ACOV, SDLS, and the LTV Mk2 are now full steam ahead to meet the deadline. With ACOV dependent on successful demonstration of Shuttle-Centaur in a few months for it's own test flights expected to start in the spring of next year. For ACOV itself, the main development difficulties are focused on the capsule itself, which is practically being turned into a Shuttleified version of the Apollo command module. With thermal blankets on the exterior, redesigned systems, a widened docking tunnel to support APAS-75, and the intention to reuse the capsules brings a lot of modifications to the table. But NASA is nevertheless confident that they can meet the current schedule, especially with support from the President and Congress.

     Speaking of the President, NASA Administrator John Young pays a visit to the White House on January 3rd, to talk about NASA's plans for the future and what they need from the President to put these into motion. The two talk alongside Reagan's Congressional advisors for a few hours, until the conversation shifts a bit. Young brings up Mars, and how JPL and Goddard are implementing a series of 4 spacecraft to pave the way for more intensive Martian exploration. Reagan asks about the agency's aspirations for manned exploration of Mars, to which Young responds very clearly that it is a top priority for the future. Over the next hour, a program is born. A silent agreement was formed between NASA, the President, and Congress that afternoon. Young left the White House with enthusiasm, but nothing was concrete yet, so it had to remain under wraps.

     For the Soviets, they are now fully focused on the development of the Three Focuses (as they are internally called) after their plans for going to the Moon with NASA fell through. Energia continues development, while Mir has now been worked through its soft redesign. Studies are being done by several design bureaus now on robotic missions for the end of the decade. However with the transfer of power following Brezhnev's death to Yuri Andropov, there is unease within those very design bureaus, and the wider space program. They will need support from the government to see these ideas realized. Andropov is mostly content to leave the space program alone, which isn't good but it isn't bad either. Effectively the Soviet space program's situation for the past decade.

     The first Shuttle of the year rolls out a bit early. Atlantis is scheduled to fly STS-61A in late January with TDRS-C, but because the Rolling Beam Umbilical System (RBUS) for Shuttle-Centaur is finally complete, there are some tests that take place on January 8th. The Centaur Integrated Support Structure (CISS) is loaded into the payload bay, and the RBUS umbilical arm is moved into position. A series of retraction tests are then performed to make sure the arm functions properly.

     With these tests completed, the CISS is removed from the payload bay, and TDRS-C loaded in for the beautiful late afternoon launch on January 22nd, 1983.

"0 and LIFTOFF of the Space Shuttle Atlantis carrying the third TDRS satellite to orbit!"

TDRS-C is deployed shortly after launch.

The crew spend the next few days on some research and experiments brought up on the Shuttle, with a landing at Edwards to conclude the mission on Flight Day 4.

     A successful mission to kick off the year, followed immediately by the cancellation of another mission.

     STS-61B was supposed to be the next mission up, manifested for Discovery carrying the GOES-F satellite. However, just 2 days after the launch of Atlantis, there are some... issues that pop up while Discovery is in the OPF. During some power up tests, it is noted that many systems do not in fact power up. Troubleshooting doesn't seem to find a solution, so they begin to dig into the problem. Several panels in the cockpit are removed to find bad wiring connections, and even just some shorted out wires for essential systems. This is the tip of the iceberg for a... small wiring problem on Discovery. There had been hints of this on previous missions, when the HUD would shutoff and come back on, a screen would cutoff and come back on, and maybe a few system glitches here and there. These issues aren't completely unheard of, but everything needing replacement will take at least a month to be isolated and fixed, which means 61B is cancelled. GOES-F is expected to launch on a Delta 3000 later in the year. NOAA (the operators of GOES) aren't exactly thrilled, but they are promised future Shuttle flights so they are mostly handled.

     Because the processing flow never stops, the already completed 61B launch stack is given to 61C, which is a DoD mission to be flown by Columbia. This is a very important mission for the DoD, and they have fought tooth and nail to get it scheduled and flown. But why? Well this mission has some background.

     The KH-9 satellite, it doesn't officially exist as far as the public is concerned but it does, physically, exist. These satellites are on their way out, to be replaced by new optical imaging satellites instead of their film-based system. However, the DoD wants to squeeze as much service time out of these satellites as possible. So, the DoD approached NASA with the idea of the Shuttle maintaining, retrieving film from, and even upgrading KH-9 satellites on orbit.

     61C's test subject will be a testbed KH-9 that failed to fully deploy and become operational when launched a few years prior. Nicknamed Oddball due to this, it will be captured by the Shuttle, and worked on during several spacewalks. 61C is also going to deploy 2 military communications satellites, but the KH-9 servicing thing is the main focus.

     Columbia launches on February 16th, 1983.

"BOOSTER IGNITION AND LIFTOFF of Space Shuttle Columbia on a mission in cooperation with the Department of Defense!"

There has started to be some visible wear on the exterior of Columbia, being the most flown Shuttle this is the most of any Orbiter. It is imperative for NASA to study how the Shuttles wear over time as it sheds light on the stresses of each orbital flight.

The first objective of the mission is deploying the MOOCS military communications satellites. They are deployed on Flight Days 2 and 3.

     On Flight Day 4, Columbia performs rendezvous with the KH-9 to be serviced, and begins a great dance in orbit to capture the spysat.

Utilizing a new RCS pack, the astronauts perform an EVA to prepare the KH-9 for capture, this includes the removal of a few things that would block the capture, including folding in the solar array as much as possible.

After this, the Shuttle captures the satellite, and the work truly begins.

 The KH-9 was captured on a new piece of equipment called the Shuttle Active Capture-Servicing Platform (SAC-SP) which, being a new system, didn't perform a perfectly aligned capture. Thus, the Astronauts perform a "Spacewalk 0" to add locking struts to fully secure the satellite to the platform.

Once this is completed, the crew return to the Shuttle and are given some time to rest.

Returning from the rest period, the crew prepare for Spacewalk 1. This spacewalk will install a new flight computer that will override the KH-9's aging avionics. Some of the most meticulous and difficult on-orbit work is done during this EVA, and many tools had to be built specifically for this spacewalk to assist the astronauts. Nevertheless after 5 hours, the computer is installed.

Spacewalk 2 refueled the KH-9's RCS thrusters, while Spacewalk 3 installed a new star tracker and an optical pathfinder camera to better select targets for observation. 

Spacewalk 5 and 6 were the final planned spacewalks, and would've attempted to install new solar arrays. However, on Flight Day 7, one of Columbia's inertial measurement units begins acting up, and while attempting to troubleshoot the issue, it fails entirely. NASA has to inform the DoD that the Shuttle has to land at the next opportunity, and the mission cannot continue. The DoD is, for lack of a better word upset, but there is nothing that can be done, the Shuttle must return. They must watch as Spacewalk 5 is repurposed to disconnect the locking struts, and preparing for the release of a non-functional KH-9.

3 hours later, the KH-9 is released from the Shuttle, completely inoperable.

Columbia then de-orbits on Flight Day 8.

The DoD is not happy about how the mission ended, but nevertheless 61C has paved the way for future on orbit servicing missions. They'll take whatever positives they can get from the mission, despite the early conclusion.

To end February, a test is conducted of the modified Lunar Module Descent Engine to be used on the ACOV service module. It will undergo a rigorous testing campaign through ground and vacuum chamber firings throughout the year.

     To kick off March, NASA representatives meet with executives from Japan's NASDA space agency in Tokyo. They are hoping to discuss options for joint Shuttle and Skylab missions. Japan has already licensed Delta rockets and currently utilize a version they have dubbed the "N-II" succeeding their previous "N-I" rocket, not to be confused with the Soviet N-1. NASDA is a hopeful agency with ambitious goals, so working with NASA and ESA could provide them with better opportunities in the future.

     The meetings are a massive success, and lay the foundation of positive relations in the future. NASDA is hopeful to get a Japanese astronaut on a 1985 Shuttle flight, which NASA is open to.

     But as new partnerships are formed, and old rocket is poised for its final flight. Grumman's Valkyrie rocket stands at LC-20 for it's final launch. The venerable light-lifter has been a workhorse for small DoD and NASA payloads since the mid-70s, with 36 previous flights, to be capped off by this final 37th. Things are changing, the Air Force would rather use its surplus of Titan missiles than continue this rocket, and Grumman doesn't want to step on it's own toes by entering Valkyrie into the commercial market, directly competing with SSV. Thus today is the final flight, carrying a Retriever-Swarm of small reconnaissance satellites for the Air Force.

The launch is successful, sending out the GAC Valkyrie on a great flight. The payloads were part of a ramping up of classified missions that has been occurring lately. But why?

Well, back on March 23rd, President Reagan made a speech from the Oval Office to the nation.

"I call upon the scientific community in our country, those who gave us nuclear weapons, to turn their great talents now to the cause of mankind and world peace, to give us the means of rendering these nuclear weapons impotent and obsolete."

     President Reagan announces the Strategic Defense Initiative, or SDI. This new program is intended to develop advanced defense systems to counter ballistic missiles and other threats by building space-based defense weaponry. The defensive part is crucial, as any "offensive weapons" in space are banned by the Outer Space Treaty, of which the US is a signatory alongside most of the world.

     Defensive weapons are a loophole, however, and the President hopes this will dissolve the concept of Mutually Assured Destruction, which he describes as a "suicide pact" by its idea of both parties of an all-out nuclear war being destroyed. This idea has hung over the heads of the nuclear superpowers since the Soviets first attained nuclear weaponry, but Reagan seeks to abolish it.

     Many are hopeful SDI will unintentionally lead to further budget increases of NASA, and the DoD has its eyes on the Space Shuttle and the upcoming SDLS rockets for usage with SDI payloads. Whatever the case, SDI has created a tense atmosphere on the world stage, and has most certainly scared the Soviets.

     With that out of the way, Discovery's wiring has finally be fixed, so the second youngest Shuttle launches on April 18th for mission 61D, carrying a new crew of Skylab and a whole load of cargo.

Discovery successfully rotates the Skylab crew, and delivers cargo. Landing occurs at Edwards Air Force Base on April 28th, 1983.

With the spring Skylab rotation complete, NASA now moves towards a very important mission...

The first flight of Shuttle-Centaur.

STS-61E, flown by Challenger, will use Centaur G to deploy the Lunar Cartographer spacecraft. This is the second mission from the Earth-Moon System Project program, and will provide the highest resolution radar maps of the lunar surface ever.

This mission is crucial to ACOV, and future deep space payloads.

MISSION OVERVIEW: STS-61E |

Commander | Karol Bobko

Pilot | Guy Gardner

Mission Specialist 1| David Hilmers

Mission Specialist 2 | Robert Springer

Payload Specialist 1 | Byron Lichtenberg

OV-099 "Challenger"

Objectives: Deploy Lunar Cartographer with Centaur G stage.

This is the first Shuttle mission with a payload specialist, a new role where people not specifically astronauts will be trained to fly on Shuttle missions.

A new era of Shuttle missions begins as Challenger lifts off into the morning skies on May 10th, 1983.

"AND LIFTOFF OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE CHALLENGER THE FIRST FLIGHT OF SHUTTLE-CENTAUR TAKES TO THE SKIES!"

Now in orbit, the Shuttle crew can breathe a sigh of relied. Shuttle-Centaur missions, while providing great capabilities, are the most dangerous the Shuttle can do. RTLS aborts (already near impossible) would require venting of Centaur's fuel in order to properly land, and the mass of the stage and payload pushes the Shuttle to its performance limit. This has earned these missions the nickname "Death Star" missions.

Nevertheless, Centaur is deployed as soon as possible, and about 2 hours later performs TLI to boost Lunar Cartographer to the Moon.

TLI is successful, and Lunar Cartographer is separated from Centaur G, deploying its radar dish and solar arrays. Centaur G will be flung into a heliocentric orbit, while Lunar Cartographer will insert into an elliptical polar mapping orbit in a week to begin its mission.

With the shiny explosive out of the payload bay, the next few days are spent on experiments and Earth photography, Challenger de-orbits on Flight Day 4 for a landing at Edwards.

     A massive step towards future missions has been made with the completion of 61E. President Reagan is at Edwards with First Lady Nancy Reagan, and they speak with the crew of the Shuttle following the landing, and the President makes a speech in front of the landed Shuttle Challenger. In this speech, he announces his government's plans to cooperate further with NASA, and mentions their upcoming suite of robotic missions to Mars. The Shuttle has become an American icon, now a focus of the Reagan administration for PR purposes. Whether being simply a PR tool for the President is ideal, it's certainly getting the budget raised every year, so NASA has no complaints on that front.

     Doubling up on Centaur missions, Atlantis is launched on STS-61F to wrap up the first half of the year for the Shuttle. This is a classified mission, so coverage is limited, but Centaur being on the mission can't be hidden due to the RBUS being obviously extended and connected. Nevertheless the mission is successful, and Shuttle-Centaur has been successfully demonstrated. 

     With 2 successful Centaur missions demonstrated, the path is clear for ACOV demonstration flights next year. The Shuttle has gone through most of its flight schedule in the first half of the year, with another flight in July and another in the autumn. This has been an unusual schedule, but 5 flights in 6 months is a positive trend in the Shuttle's flight cadence. The Shuttle's turnaround time is the main thing keeping it from flying even more consistently, which has been a point of focus from several Rockwell and NASA studies about future upgrades. Including one presented this month in the Space Shuttle Technical Report from Dryden and Ames. These reports have for a long time been advocating for Shuttle upgrades, and they're starting to gain traction.

     Meanwhile across the pond, the UKSA has been gaining political relevance, as their Comet B rocket will be providing many new jobs across the UK. NASA has also gotten interested in the project, and has begun discussing possible joint projects with the UKSA.

     For the Soviets, they are still grinding away at Energia development, with test articles and engine development coming along as of the summer. VKK is also beginning construction for its first flights in a few years.

     But as late June rolls around, there's one thing on the minds of everybody in the world of spaceflight.

Iapyx is about to enter orbit of Saturn.
