Saturn and A Series of Spacecraft

June 26th, 1983

"We're uh, patiently awaiting the completion of orbital insertion, here at JPL Mission Control."

"Just about 1 minute left in orbital insertion."

"Data is looking good."

"20 seconds."

"Confirmation of main engine shutdown!"

"Now awaiting the data return."

"..."

"And we have a NOMINAL CONFIRMATION OF SATURN ORBIT, THE IAPYX SPACECRAFT HAS BECOME THE FIRST TO ORBIT SATURN."

"We're getting the instrument data back now... oh my it's beautiful."

     3 years since its departure from Earth, Iapyx has officially become the first spacecraft to orbit Saturn. After many years of hard work from countless men and women, this bold little robotic spacecraft has done what so many have dreamed and hope for since the 1960s. JPL is ecstatic, as the pictures return, and Iapyx swings back out away from Saturn, revealing stunning views. The mission has been not only a physical success, but a massive one in the realm of public relations. Iapyx represents a revival of robotic missions that is soon to come, and the ability of NASA to continue to pioneer in all fields of space exploration. President Reagan receives a debriefing with photos and data from the spacecraft 2 days later, on June 28th. He then makes a speech to the nation, congratulation JPL and NASA on their achievements, and asking the country to follow the discoveries of the mission as it begins an incredible new phase of exploration.

     Iapyx will sit in Saturn orbit until October, when it will then attempt it's first flyby of Saturn's largest Moon, and the mission's highest priority target (other than Saturn itself), Titan. The moon will give Iapyx a boost towards the next flyby of the outermost major moon of Saturn, Iapetus. The flyby of Iapetus will be retrograde, pulling the spacecraft back down towards Saturn for a tour of the inner moons. This flyby process preserves fuel and maximizes mission lifespan. 

     The pictures being returned are already mesmerizing the world, revealing new detail in the rings, and providing fascinating insights into the cloud structure of Saturn. With its massive suite of instruments, Iapyx is revealing new things about the Saturnian system with every return of data. There are so many wonders left to be discovered, and NASA is enthusiastic about this mission.

     A billion miles away, back on Earth. Things are shaking up to be uhh... rather anticlimactic for the second half of the year. 2 more Shuttle missions in the span of 5 months. But there are lots of interesting developments going on regardless of the Shuttle's absence in the second half of the year. ESA and the UKSA are planning to begin test flights of the MPCS on Ariane 1 at the end of the year, followed by the first uncrewed Coelus mission at the start of next year. They are very enthusiastic, and have been garnering world interest over the past few months.

     Meanwhile, for the Soviets, it is time for their inconsistently often "Let's try out TKS" mission, this time on Sokol. TKS has been in limbo ever since it first flew, as an attempt to replace Soyuz that has never gotten fully off the ground. With the upcoming development of VKK it is uncertain whether TKS will survive, although its project managers remain hopeful for more funding.

     Sokol appears to be an ideal launch platform for TKS, although the boosters are likely unnecessary. Recently there has been quite a bit of interest in TKS from the Soviet government, and it may have a future as a Soyuz replacement to operate alongside VKK. However, with recent... words by Ronald Reagan and the announcement of SDI, the Soviet military has been further entrenched as the dominant budget. All the space program can do is hope for funding to either stay consistent or increase. It appears, however, that the Soviet government sees the space program, finally, as a valuable propaganda tool. They have warmed to the idea of propping it up again as they did in the late 50s and early 60s. This is the Soviet space program's hope for the future, similar to NASA's.

    As July begins, America's beloved Space Shuttle Enterprise rolls out for launch. The oldest Shuttle has been entrusted with an important mission for the future of the program. This mission, STS-61G, was originally a Shuttle rideshare mission, but payload delays have lead NASA to bump those commercial payloads to the next rideshare mission, and designate 61G a mission for some little NASA payloads, and a very important test. You see, the Space Shuttle's mission duration is limited by its fuel cells, which are the primary source of power. On top of this,  the Shuttle can only carry so much hydrogen and oxygen for them to use to generate power. However they can be slowed down to consume less hydrogen and oxygen, increasing the time until they run out. But this would result in the Shuttle having less power and therefore might not function well. To supplement the loss of power, engineers at Ames designed what they call the Orbital Mission Length ExTension (OMLET). OMLET, with its incredible backronym, is a power bus that can be placed in the payload bay of the Shuttle, with a large, state-of-the-art solar array to generate extra power for the Shuttle. Combining the fuel cell overhead and the extra solar power, this could allow for Shuttle missions up to 20 days in duration. However that is likely only possible with Challenger, which has extra hydrogen and oxygen storage for the fuel cells. The other Shuttles are likely capable of 18 days. This mission will not draw power from OMLET, but it will measure how much power is generated over several days, thus providing invaluable data for operational usage.

     Enterprise begins an essential voyage on July 4th, 1983.

"2..., 1... ZERO, BOOSTER IGNITION AND LIFTOFF OF ENTERPRISE! Delivering spacecraft to orbit and preparing for extended duration Shuttle missions!"

The other 2 payloads on the mission are being stored in sunshades. These are NASA's Deep Space Relay Experiment (DeSpRE) which is intended to test better methods of orbital deep space communication, and 4 COmpact RAdar Satellites (CORSAs) which are operated in collaboration with USC. So technically 5 other payloads. There is also a panoramic camera at the front of the payload bay for capturing images of payload deployment.

DeSpRE and CORSA will be deployed first, before OMLET is utilized towards the end of the mission.

Finally, on Flight Day 7, OMLET's solar array is extended.

The kilowatt output from the solar array is promising, and data is collected over three days.

On Flight Day 10, Enterprise returns for a landing at the Cape, where the landing restriction has been lifted, as this is the first flight with the improved nose wheel steering system.

     A successful mission concluded. For Enterprise, she will be sent to Palmdale now for some... modifications. This is because Enterprise will be serving out of Vandenberg for the forseeable future, and must therefore represent her service to the Department of Defense with some upgrades and livery changes. NASA feels rather clever about giving the DoD the oldest Shuttle to fly, but the DoD couldn't care less, they just want dedicated Shuttle missions, and they are finally getting them.

     It's July and there's only one more Shuttle mission to go, yet it has flown 6 times already. A few mission cancellations have cut the manifest short for the year, but it has regardless been an impressive year for the Space Shuttle, and 1984 is planned to have a 9 flight manifest, assuming more missions don't get cancelled. NASA is also working on new "work overflow hangars" behind the Orbiter Processing Facility which will allow for Shuttles that need a bit less work to be handled, decreasing the strain on processing and hopefully increasing maximum flight capabilities.

     The rest of July is quiet, but on August 3rd... NASA has a special delivery.

     Fresh from Michoud, the first SDLS core stage has arrived at the Kennedy Space Center. This is a momentous occasion. With the stage now delivered, NASA expects the first launch of SDLS to be in the first 2 quarters of 1984. The SRB segments have already arrived, and the upper stage is due to be delivered at the start of 1984. The pieces are now falling into place for the debut of SDLS. 

     On August 26th, Iapyx performs its first flyby of Titan. Hundreds of people gather at JPL to see the first images, only to get nothing... Concerning for the team, and disappointing for the public. However it appears to have been just a minor issue, the camera has a "sleep" mode and when a flyby begins it is told to "wake up" from this mode, at least in a normal case. The code to actually wake up the camera appears to not have worked as intended, and the team send commands to forget the sleep mode and make it a simple on/off for the camera. A test verifies this works by sending back a picture of Saturn on August 29th. But on the bright side, all other instruments collected heaps of data, and some of the other imaging instruments provided photos, although not in true color. The flyby shows just how much data Iapyx can return. Iapyx is now intended to simply sit in Saturn orbit for a study phase until the time is right for the Iapetus flyby in late 1984.

To cap off the year for NASA, Atlantis launches on STS-61I to deliver a new crew to Skylab and bring supplies. The mission is successful, and lands back at the Cape on November 16th, 1983 after a 10 day mission.

To conclude the year, ESA and the UK Space Agency will have their moment in the spotlight. On December 16th, Ariane 1 launches with an uncrewed MPCS to verify the launch vehicle for crewed MPCS missions to the Coelus Lab, and perform tests of some upgraded MPCS systems.

After a day in orbit, MPCS uses its new solid motors (intended for whatever kind of aborts that might be needed) to de-orbit. However, the trajectory is off and the descent is too steep, coming into the lower atmosphere much hotter than planned. But flying pizza roll does what it can to slow down, and the paraglider deploys. However, rough seas cause the MPCS to tip over after splashdown.

Despite this landing tomfoolery, Ariane 1 was certified to carry crew with this mission, and necessary adjustments to MPCS will be made. Overall, Coelus remains on schedule.

     However, on December 24th...

     Rockwell sends NASA an early Christmas present.

ACOV has arrived.

YEAHHHHHHH BABY
What does ACOV stand for again? There's a lot of acronyms in this mission report...

Orwellian Year

     In his 1949 novel, author George Orwell depicted a dystopian reality set in the year 1984. As we enter this famed year, we are thankfully not in Orwell's dystopian reality. But in one filled with optimism for space exploration and scientific achievement. But over this excitement sets unease. The Cold War has gotten noticeably colder in the past few years, as President Reagan has taken a harsh stance towards the Soviet Union. The Strategic Defense Initiative has appeared to frighten the Soviets even more, and they appear to be ramping up production of nuclear weapons and ballistic missiles. On top of massively increasing the Soviet military budget. The US has responded in kind, as the threat posed by the Soviets has further solidified SDI as a necessary program in the eyes of many, including Congress.

     Impending doom aside, NASA has massive plans for this year. 2 missions to Mars will be launched, ACOV will fly for the first time, SDLS will too, and the budget continues to steadily rise. The FY 1984 budget is placed at 10 billion dollars (about 29 billion today) which is a major leap up. With this funding, NASA feels ready to make a major announcement. 

     At the Kennedy Space Center, the Stacking & Assembly Building (SAB) has finally been completed! This building can hold Shuttle launch stacks (ET and SRBs) as well as core stages for SDLS and boosters. This will take a lot of the load off of the VAB and reduce strain on the processing flow. With this major addition complete, NASA can see the launch cadence of the Shuttle increasing over the next few years. 

     To kick off the year, Challenger launches STS-71A on January 9th. This mission has 2 objectives. The first being to repair the Solar Maximum Mission, which was launched in February 1980. However, in November of that year, it suffered an attitude control failure. The Shuttle is now set to repair the spacecraft and return it to operational status. The other objective is to retrieve the LDEF, which Challenger deployed in 1980 on that memorably hectic launch.

On Flight Day 3, Solar Maximum is in position for capture.

The Shuttle captures the spacecraft, and work begins a few hours later.

The crew perform 3 spacewalks to repair SolarMax. These consist of replacing the entire attitude control system module, and the electronics module for the coronagraph/polarimeter instrument. A gas cover is also installed for the over the X-ray polychromator. 

After these successful repairs, SolarMax is released and sent on its merry way.

After this, Challenger performs a maneuver to rendezvous with the LDEF for its retrieval, reaching everyone's favorite 12 sided space cylinder on Flight Day 5.

Challenger's flight that launched LDEF caused quite the stir due to what happened on ascent with one of the main engines. However this is a far less chaotic event, assuming the Canadarm cooperates. The Shuttle slowly moves in, readying the Canadarm for capture.

After about 45 minutes of shenanigans, Canadarm has captured the LDEF.

It takes another 90 minutes, but the LDEF is finally secured in the payload bay, and Challenger prepares to return home.

Challenger is diverted to a landing at Wallops Flight Facility, a new alternative landing site with a runway completed last spring. This is due to poor weather at the Cape, the original landing site.

     Despite the unexpected landing location, the mission is a complete success, and a good start to the Shuttle's busy year.

     After a year in planning, NASA is finally ready to make its big announcement on January 21st. President Reagan visits the National Air & Space Museum, and makes a speech on the steps of the building to the nation, and the world.

     "My fellow Americans, I speak to you today from the steps of the National Air & Space Museum. It is truly a remarkable place, dedicated to preserving this nation's aerospace history. But we are still writing that very history, pushing the boundaries of what is considered possible for mankind to accomplish. Our nation's incredible space agency, NASA, with its fleet of Shuttles, new spacecraft, and many scientific missions, has for the past 25 years amazed us all with their feats of engineering and science. From a child sitting in the family living room as Neil Armstrong took his first steps onto the lunar surface, or as tens of thousands of people watched the Space Shuttle lift off into the skies for the first time. We are still pushing the boundaries of what is possible, and that is why I am here today."

     "For centuries, mankind has looked up to a red dot in the sky. The Romans named it in honor of their god of war, Mars. Since then, we've learned a lot about this dusty red ball, and we've been amazed by it every step of the way. Human exploration of Mars is one of the most ambitious steps we will take as a species in the next several hundred years, and that is what we are beginning the process today. Ladies and Gentleman, our nation is beginning an exploration program to achieve a human landing on Mars by the turn of the century. In honor of one of the world's greatest and most legendary explorers, it will be named the Magellan program."

     "This is one of our nation's greatest endeavors, and it will fulfill the dreams and imaginations of countless who have come before us, and those to come after us.  A golden age of exploration is just beginning, and the United States intends to lead it. Thank you, and God Bless America."

        World news is electric following the announcement. Americans feel like they're getting a bit of deja vu, as Carter's attempt with the Aris program fell back into a development program that will actually now help Magellan. But this is different, setting the goal to before 2000 makes this very realistically achievable. The Reagan admin is willing to pony up the funding to make it happen as well, so there is a different feeling with the announcement this time around. NASA feels actually prepared to take on this challenge, and they've set out a reasonable timeframe to do it. The following is NASA's initial schedule for Magellan.

  • 1984: Finalized concept studies
  • 1985: Development of concepts
  • 1986: Contracts go out for essential hardware
  • 1987: Contracts for minor hardware
  • 1988: Construction on essential hardware begins
  • 1989: Construction on minor hardware begins
  • 1990: Construction complete, first flight

     While the first flight date might be a bit optimistic, the development pace is achievable, and work to expand Michoud for dedicated transfer vehicle assembly is already in the final phase of planning before construction begins.

     As the news begins to cool down after the announcement, ESA and the UKSA make their next big step towards crewed Coelus missions. The first Coelus Lab is launched aboard the first Ariane 3 on February 10th, 1984.

     The Coelus Lab is at the very edge of Ariane 3's capabilities, and in fact it had to be re-designed because it was too heavy for it. But those issues aside, it is finally in orbit. This Lab will service both the MPCS test flight and the first crewed flight, which is currently slated for April. The uncrewed MPCS is set to arrive in 3 weeks.

     Indeed it does arrive in 3 weeks. On March 5th, Ariane 1 lifts the uncrewed pizza roll into the skies for this crucial test mission. This flight is also important because it is the first time MPCS is using its new Coelus Module, which is a new aft "service module" of sorts that holds 2 large solar arrays and the docking port, as well as eventually an airlock for crews. The mission is completely successful, and MPCS returns to Earth 3 days after launch.

     The path is now clear for the first crewed launch of MPCS, now scheduled for May after some unexpected delays to the delivery of the spacecraft. This is tolerable however as Coelus Lab's orbit is calculated to not decay until 1985. But with some time until that mission, the Shuttle is scheduled to make its debut at a new launch site. The DoD's patience has finally paid off, as Space Shuttle Enterprise is stacked at Launch Complex 6 at Vandenberg Air Force Base, for the first West Coast Shuttle launch.

     This is a monumental moment for both the DoD and NASA. Although she is now clad with an Air Force insignia on her side and "USA" in the Amarillo Air Force font on the tail, she remains a NASA Space Shuttle, with the iconic red worm above the name on the right wing. Although the primary use for now is national security missions, NASA sees potential in civilian flights from Vandenberg.

     On April 10th, a crew of highly trained Air Force astronauts board Shuttle Enterprise, and prepare for a great first in the Shuttle Program.

"Main engine start... 2... 1..."

"Solid Motor Ignition and Liftoff."

"Copy Liftoff."

"Roll Program."

"Roger."

     Despite noticeable wear across the vehicles tiles and thermal blankets beginning to develop, Enterprise remains as steady and as capable as ever, now with a slight livery update to represent her national security service. Enterprise has, though, taken a backseat in NASA's eyes to the newer and more capable shuttles, which made it the perfect Orbiter to let the Air Force do their missions with. This mission played host to many firsts, including the first flight with the new striking black Filament Wound Casing SRBs, which are planned to eventually be used at Cape Canaveral, pending modifications to launch infrastructure.

     The Air Force crew regardless have nothing but compliments for the Space Shuttle, as they prepare to begin their mission in orbit. Which... wait what is their mission? Well, as you may remember, early last year Columbia "serviced" a KH-9 spy satellite, to less than optimal effect, however that was a testbed satellite to prove that it could be done. Now Enterprise is going to perform this for the first time operationally. The DoD has been preparing for this for quite some time, as all KH-9s launched since 1974 have a "film retrieval system" which allows astronauts to retrieve film from the satellite on a spacewalk, giving the satellite life beyond the use of its film buckets.

     On Flight Day 2, Enterprise has caught up to this monolithic spy satellite.

     Shenanigans ensue, as capturing the KH-9 remains a difficult task. The DoD has kept this in mind for its new generation of spysats, which no longer utilize film, and will simply be upgraded, boosted, and repaired by the Shuttle. They will be equipped with fixtures for the Canadarm, and proper capture ports. The DoD is also experimenting with these features on the final 3 KH-9 satellites to be launched, one of which is already in orbit. Nevertheless this doesn't help the crew of STS-72A, as they are having to maneuver in with a literal claw to grab onto "pressure points" on the KH-9 service module. These pressure points are in a very awkward position, as the solars and orbital engine block a capture from the bottom. Oddball could simply be taken apart to get a clean capture, but the DoD would rather avoid that with this functional unit.

     Eventually, with some world-class space maneuvering, Enterprise has hold of the mighty spysat, and work can begin.

     Relatively speaking, the workload on this satellite is light, it is a newer unit launched in 1979, and is still functioning well. The DoD just wants the film retrieved, and some experimental upgrades, as well as some maintenance, completed. A new override control module is installed, as well as a new electronics control module, and the satellite is refueled from a fuel canister on the front of the capture platform. With this, and the film retrieval, this satellite will likely receive one more visit before being left to retirement and eventual deorbit.

     To the DoD's delight, the Shuttle's IMUs behave themselves, and the servicing of the satellite is fully completed by Flight Day 6, with a gentle release, putting it back into operational service. 

     On Flight Day 8, Enterprise de-orbits for a landing back at Vandenberg Air Force Base.

"300 feet."

"200."

"100."

"50."

"20."

"10."

"5."

"Main Gear Touchdown."

"Nose Gear Touchdown."

"Wheel Stop."

"Copy, Wheel Stop."

     Under California clouds, the first West Coast Shuttle mission has been completed. The DoD is thrilled to finally have their own Space Shuttle operations, and will have Enterprise at Vandenberg until 1987, when there will be a swap to another Shuttle, most likely Discovery.

     Regardless, Enterprise will be taken to Palmdale for some work, and fly another classified mission soon. While ESA now prepares for a monumental step, their first independent manned mission. Taking to the skies on May 16th, with a 5-man crew composed of 2 Frenchman, 2 Germans, and 1 Englishman.

 

 

Once in orbit, the solar arrays are deployed, and MPCS sets up for a rendezvous with the Coelus Lab the next day. Orienting towards the sun because the solars are not capable of tracking it.

26 hours later, MPCS arrives at the Lab for docking.

"30."

"20."

"15."

"10."

"5."

"2."

"1."

"Contact!"

"Amarrage dur confirmé !"

     A monumental achievement for ESA and the UKSA. The stay will be brief, only 4 days, so there are many tests performed to ensure Coelus Lab is indeed comfortable for crews. When all is said and done, MPCS departs the station, and returns for quite possibly its last splashdown in the Atlantic Ocean. All future flights are going to land on... well land. The landing skid pads were actually installed on MPCS, although they are non-functional. MPCS also continues to use its "expendable" forward RCS thrusters on the front, this is going to be changed for operational crewed flights scheduled to start at the end of the year.

     With that, ESA has become the third space agency to fly humans into space. World news covers the mission each day, and it has rallied Western Europe behind ESA, as a source of pride for their nations. Both NASA and the Soviets congratulate ESA, although the Soviets seem less enthusiastic about the achievement than NASA. Japan has struck a deal to fly an astronaut next year on MPCS, on top of their agreements to fly on a Shuttle mission. As NASA gains more and more partners, the Soviets continue to be isolated, and will be forced to make big leaps over the coming years to keep pace.

     Back at the Cape, however, NASA is preparing for its own monumental mission to round out the second half of the year. This mission has been highly anticipated for a few years now, and it sets into motion the next phase of lunar exploration.

     The first flight of ACOV.

     Under the massive lights of LC-39A, as the summer sun is a few hours out from rising on June 10th, 1984, Space Shuttle Atlantis is set to take flight on STS-71E, the first of 2 planned test flights for ACOV, with this one being intended to demonstrate life support systems, propulsion, power, and other key functions with crew aboard. The Shuttle is carrying 5 crew, 3 of which will board ACOV, attached to an enlarged Centaur G' known as "Super Centaur" which will boost them out into an elliptical High Earth Orbit. They will orbit a few times, while doing a second orbit boost using ACOV's own main engine, before de-orbiting and landing north of Hawaii in the Pacific Ocean.

"Solid Rocket Motor Ignition and LIFTOFF! LIFTOFF of Atlantis and the first ACOV spacecraft!"

     Once in orbit, the crew must still quickly get Centaur and ACOV out of the payload bay, as standard Shuttle-Centaur practice. The 3 crew of ACOV (Richard Covey, Dale Gardner, and Franklin Chiang-Diaz) board the spacecraft through a retractable crew tunnel that connects to the APAS-75 port's docking latches, it is a rather compact system, but it works with the minimal space available. After all 3 crew have their pressure suits on, and are firmly seated, the tunnel is depressurized and retracting, clearing the way for the CISS (Centaur Integrated Support System) to begin rotating the stack out of the payload bay of Atlantis. The first step is to a 23 degree rotation, called the "checkout position" where final systems checks are made.     

    Following this, the CISS rotates up to 45 degrees for release.

     "Alright, copy Houston. This is ACOV and everything is GO on our end."

    "Roger that, ACOV. Atlantis, Houston, you have the GO for release."

     "Houston, Atlantis, we copy and we are GO for release."

     "10 seconds to release."

     "5."

     "3."

     "2."

     "1."

     "RELEASE LIGHT."

     "Confirmed release."

     With the boost maneuver for ACOV near orbital sunset, they make as much separation from the Shuttle as they can, and not too long after, the 2 RL10 engines light up to boost ACOV into an elliptical orbit.

     Orbiting around the Earth, the crew capture fantastic photos, before coming back down for a test of ACOV's main engine to further boost the orbit.

     A little while later, ACOV de-orbits for a landing north of Hawaii in the Pacific Ocean.

     Despite the rather rough splashdown, ACOV's first test flight has been a great success, and fully certified the vehicle. Atlantis lands at Edwards on June 16th, concluding STS-71E.

     The second and last test flight is scheduled to take place at the start of next year, and will be a full circumlunar flight, although it will not enter orbit as ACOV requires refueling to return to Earth from lunar orbit.

     Speaking of that, as the first half of the year comes to a close. NASA shows the public the first photos of the in construction Propulsion and Control Module (PCM) for the Tranquility station. On top of this, the depot modules, and the first Autonomous Lunar Refueling Vehicle, are now under construction. The ALRV's development has been rather quiet, but it is essentially a tanker based off of the Apollo Block III service module for refueling the depot modules of Tranquility.

     With all of these busy developments, and Magellan announced, NASA finally gives the Apollo Follow-On Program its own name. Fittingly, the program has been named after a child of Apollo.

Orpheus

     Now with a fancy name, the Orpheus program remains on track for 1985. But as the first half of the year comes to a close, there are busy developments in the VAB...

SDLS is stacked and ready for its inaugural launch.
